comments.body:
i just noticed this new sub path (and v prefix)

could you please add the following second sentence in the release note:
> The v1.8.0 image is now located in a "coredns" sub-path and the tag is prefixed with "v": k8s.gcr.io/coredns/coredns:v1.8.0

in case someone assumes the image is at `k8s.gcr.io/coredns:1.8.0`

you can `/hold cancel` after that and the PR should merge.

When we make custom Kind node image, it does have an assumption on `k8s.gcr.io/coredns:1.8.0`,
now it breaks the basic workflow of making custom kind node image.

the question is why we are making a change on path? @rajansandeep cc @neolit123
just noting that if one day we want to *not* use a certain version of coredns with a version of k8s, we may have to introduce the same mapping / table as the one for etcd on line 448.

comment above should start with PodSubnetNodeMaxDiff on the first line.

i tried to reword this, please change if needed.

> // PodSubnetNodeMaskMaxDiff is limited to 16 due to an issue with uncompressed IP bitmap in core:
> // xref: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/44918
> // The Node subnet mask size must be no more than the Pod subnet mask size + 16

did we had a ticket for that in k/k that we can link to from here?
maybe have a `TODO: ...` to update this once/if the bitmap problems are resolved?
added the kep that explains the whole thing
@neolit123 - If someone rollbacks would the node object still have this taint ? (thus preventing potential user services running the control plane from scheduling) ?

In this pr we are not yet adding the taint to node objects. But your concern is valid when we start doind that. Potentially if kubeadm upgrade fails, we could have logic to remove the taint near the step of restoring the backed up manifests.
Note: manually edited this line after running the cherrypick script.

see my example, you can find a matching version using the loop. it seems better to me.
[3]

a non-blocking wonder what this will do.
my guess it will only apply to new clusters and existing clusters will have to opt-in manually for this sandbox update for dockershim, as kubeadm upgrade does not manage this at all.

cc @rosti @bart0sh

Yes. That's because we supply that image only with the `--pod-infra-container-image` when we generate the kubelet env file. However, we don't regenerate that file upon upgrade (only on initial kubelet setup). Hence, users who only do upgrades would not get the new pause version.
But then again, `--pod-infra-container-image` only works with Docker...
yeah, annoyingly this is otherwise handled in config of the CRI implementation and not specified by CRI / kubelet. we'll need to update those as well.
https://github.com/containerd/cri/pull/1399

when we originally discussed this there were also comments about using exponential backoff.
i'm fine with using 5 retries, but let's see if anyone has more comments.

exp. backoff will make this harder to unit test.

[1]

We need to keep it like `LabelNodeRoleMaster`. There is currently a constant named in the same way and used for the same purpose in `pkg/controller/service/service_controller.go` and the idea is at some point to move that constant to a common place (where we won't import a huge package just for it).
Until then, it's best to keep the constant names in sync.
ok, keeping this like so.
Nit: you may remove the 10 and 11 statements, they're not used anymore
Removed
The version in the [upgrade tests](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/cmd/kubeadm/app/phases/upgrade/compute_test.go) also need to be changed.
This is the key name used in kube-proxy manifest.. just refactored in a constant because it is now used in different places.

@luxas a couple of notes:

1) 
```
key: value---
```
i think the above would trigger the separator, where `---` could be intended as being part of `value`.

could be the safer way to do this.
`YAMLDocumentSeparator = "\n---\n"`

2)
`\n` would only handle the Unix (POSIX), LF case.
does the file loading instrumentation in k8s convert e.g CRLF (`\r\n`) line endings to LF `\n` automatically?
things like `ioutil.ReadFile()` do not, which means that if the user created his config file with CRLF endings it would look like this:

`\r\n---\r\n` == `13 10 45 45 45 13 10`

OSX sanely moved to LF a while ago, while some editors on Windows are still CRLF by default.

^ so it seems the reader comes from api machinery, so 1) is handled by using `\n---`. not ideal but it's better than `---\n`.
2) is not handled it seems.

the separator constant should be exported from here IMO:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/staging/src/k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/yaml/decoder.go#L139
Practically all text editors on Windows (apart from Notepad) support Unix style line endings and UTF-8 these days, so I don't think that this is much of a problem here.
that's true, but the parser has to be CRLF ready. otherwise - breakage.
This is only used for serialization, not deserialization. So I'm not sure these comments apply

yeah, this is fine for now.
i'm going to test the api machinery code in terms of CRLF and things like that, soon.
great :+1:
I'm genuinely surprised that I couldn't find a utility f(n) in k8s land that didn't do this.
Can you make a constant for this or use one of the formats defined in `time`?

If I am understanding the docs for [Dynamic Kubelet Config](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/reconfigure-kubelet/), it looks like the dynamic config is downloaded from the config map to the directory specified by `--dynamic-config-dir` automatically and the config pulled down overrides the values that are set through `--config`. With that being the case, shouldn't we write the static config file (or initial config in the case of dynamic config) to `/etc/kubernetes` and leave `/var/lib/kubelet` for the content that is dynamically managed at runtime by the kubelet?
How about just `client.crt`? Then multiple clients can re-use
I'm not positive we should generalize the usage of a cert that allows access to the cluster's data.

~how's `etcd/client-apiserver` ?~

edit: I ended up not nesting this client cert under the new `etcd/` subdir.
This line is just to make the test pass. Should bump to 3.2.12 done in #57230

please require the caller to pass in a `*version.Version` here instead of parsing things yourself inline here
I don't want this func to return an error
please add an unit test for this :)
If somebody passes k8s version which is not on the list?

Another thing that bug me, on one hand we tried to hide details from the user of this function (removing converting to uint8 in the previous revision of this pr) which make sense, but here you suggest to force the user to convert to version.Version? I am trying to understand the logic here.
ok, I'm not feeling very strongly here, so as you added the unit test I'm fine with this :)
you can use `MustParseSemantic` here as you control the constants
what would be the rational of using one instead of this one?
just return nil in this (should be impossible) case?
what if somebody select k8s version which is not on the list and it does not get caught earlier, would it not be safer to react with an error?

@kubernetes/sig-network-api-reviews 

This doesn't follow the convetions of other labels in this file, nor does it have any versioning. Are we committing to this API?
Sorry I screwed up the cut/paste I guess. I'm happy to add the dash instead of the dot...
For completeness are these tested?  I don't see them.
Added unit tests for completeness, thanks.
root only on TempDir?
yes; we concluded that there are possible, pretty nasty `/tmp`-dir attacks where lots of users can do things; so we moved the upgrade temp dir to `/etc/kubernetes/tmp` with root-only access
These users and groups look correct.

I wondered, do we have these easily accessible anywhere else?
Without dependency hell, you know ;)

In our experience, people will probably want a "starting point" kubeconfig that doesn't have an identity, but does have the server connection information in it.  Doesn't have to be in this pull, but it's likely to come up.

`kubeadm alpha phase kubeconfig token --client-name foo --api-server https://ip-here --token bar` will give you that nearly that. It will output the kubeconfig to stdout with the token, but it's very easy to just remove the bar token afterwards.

We might consider a `kubeadm alpha phase kubeconfig basic` or `bare` or `server-only` or something if there's need

Also -- this is the "cluster info" stuff that we put in the configmap for discovery bootstrap.  The goal was to make this be the way to go and get this stuff.  (`namespace/kube-public/configmaps/cluster-info`).

comments.body: Is this a pre-existing path from somewhere or is it net new?  I'm just not very familiar with the tool.

This exists already as an environment variable option, but I'm registering this here now so I can gradually expose this as a flag and the API in different places and get rid of the env param(s) totally
@smarterclayton
This is acceptable to use here given the discussion on the other PR.
Do we want to add and label nodes too?
Maybe, but that's for the deb packages... (`--node-labels=foobar` kubelet flag)
is the switch to a hard-coded absolute path new? seems like that would make testing difficult

It isn't new. We decided on making these params hard coded -- at least until we have the full config file backend to rely on where the user can specify params that are passed directly to the apiserver/cm/scheduler

comments.body: not sure about this as a fixed, non-overrideable path

It's a fine line between overridability and sprawl. Regarding this one, we decided in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubeadm/pull/156 that `/etc/kubernetes` should be a constant -- it doesn't make sense to override that really.
Also, this isn't new for this PR. If you have very strong opinions -- please file an issue and we'll see but it's not the main thing in this PR

comments.body: This will become `0` (token doesn't expire)
Not sure what this comment means. Are you going to change this to 0?  I think that is probably a compatible default.
Yes, I'm gonna change it to `0` later, just wanna stay away from functional changes here
This will become a prefix instead: `system:bootstrapper:`+`<tokenid>`
is it `system:bootstrapper` or `system:bootstrap`?
Oh, recalled incorrectly, yes `system:bootstrap:` as we decided in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/41281
This will become `system:bootstrappers`
If we're enforcing 1.6 and defaulting to RBAC, why is this needed then?

You're right; it's not used anywhere, but I guess it might be there for completeness, since we were told to copy these constants from another package (which also have these constants). They were copied over here to kubeadm until a subpackage is made for the authorizer that includes only the constants.
Hmmmm OK.

Sorry for that strange comment above; I'm a little bit tired :)
Basically we have to duplicate the constants unless we want the binary to grow twice the size or so because of all the other packages that would follow. This can be fixed in the future when the authorizer package is a bit more refactored
cc @liggitt @deads2k
